Document Title: AI-Powered Automated Criticism Design Tool Based on Texts and its Themes
Authors: K. Saddhono; N. Saputra; E. Saragih; E. L. B. Rumapea; S. N. Tarigan; C. Hasanudin
Author Affiliations: Universitas Sebelas Maret, Surakarta, Indonesia; Sekolah Tinggi Ilmu Tarbiyah Al Hilal, Sigli, Indonesia; Universitas Sumatera Utara, Medan, Indonesia; Sekolah Tinggi Ilmu Ekonomi Petra, Bitung, Indonesia; Universitas Prima Indonesia, Medan, Indonesia; IKIP PGRI Bojonegoro, Indonesia
Publication Title: 2024 4th International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
Abstract: Its use in literary criticism might be one of the most novel opportunities to analyze texts and themes since artificial intelligence (AI) touches and improves every facet of human life. This paper has detailed issues on the application of AI-powered literary criticism and an overview of methodologies, applications, and implications accompanying the adoption of AI technologies. The paper starts with the context in which AI has actually emerged as one of the hot topics in literary studies, emanating from the crossroads of computational linguistics, natural language processing, and machine learning. “The true research opportunity that thus emerges from this work is the development of new AI technologies that can help supplement and augment traditional practices of literary analysis in such a way that scholars can get deeper into texts in search of the sorts of patterns and meanings that interest them. This paper presents illustrative examples and case studies in the applications of AI to literary criticism, which include sentiment analysis, topic modelling, and stylometric analysis. What these techniques afford researchers is a set of tools capable of processing large corpora of text with such accuracy and speed that identifying recurring motifs, characters dynamics, and thematic elements over genres, and literary periods is no problem. The following paper considers the ethical issues at the heart of AI-powered literary criticism, calling into question the algorithmic bias of authorship attribution and interpretive tasks it currently automates.
Author Keywords: AI-Powered Literary Criticism;Artificial Intelligence;Textual Analysis;Thematic Analysis;Stylometric Analysis;Algorithmic Bias;Ethical Considerations;Interdisciplinary Collaboration

Document Title: Leveraging Machine Learning Techniques for Predictive Maintenance and Fault Detection in Industrial Systems
Authors: G. Sukhani; M. Gulhane; N. Rakesh; S. Maurya; S. Choudhary; S. Pandey
Author Affiliations: Symbiosis Institute of Technology, Nagpur Campus, Symbiosis International (Deemed University), Pune, India; Symbiosis Institute of Technology, Nagpur Campus, Symbiosis International (Deemed University), Pune, India; Symbiosis Institute of Technology, Nagpur Campus, Symbiosis International (Deemed University), Pune, India; Symbiosis Institute of Technology, Nagpur Campus, Symbiosis International (Deemed University), Pune, India; Neil Gogte Institute of Technology, Hyderabad, India; Graphic Era Hill University, Bhimtal Campus, India
Publication Title: 2024 4th International Conference on Technological Advancements in Computational Sciences (ICTACS)
Abstract: Generative adversarial networks (GANs) have achieved remarkable success in image synthesis, but evaluating their quality remains an open challenge. Existing automated metrics like FID are unable to fully capture generation performance across both objective fidelity and subjective aesthetic attributes important to human perception. This paper conducts an extensive review of the literature on GAN evaluation methodology. Key limitations of current approaches are analyzed through a discussion of popular metrics and their inability to predict human judgment comprehensively. To address this, a novel hybrid evaluation model is proposed that combines automated scores with human ratings to provide a more balanced assessment. A pilot study demonstrates the hybrid metric can predict human response more accurately.
Author Keywords: Generative adversarial networks;GANs;Evaluation metrics;Model assessment;Human evaluation;Subjective attributes;Automatic scores;Hybrid evaluation;Computational creativity;Interactive frameworks;Generative capacity;Artistic exploration;Image synthesis;Deep learning
IEEE Terms: Measurement;Training;Reviews;Computational modeling;Machine learning;Generative adversarial networks;Real-time systems;Informatics;Creativity;Predictive maintenance

Document Title: Social Network Modeling and Agent-Based Simulation in Support of Crisis De-Escalation
Authors: M. J. Lanham; G. P. Morgan; K. M. Carley
Author Affiliations: Center for Computational Analysis of Social and Organizational Systems, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, USA; Center for Computational Analysis of Social and Organizational Systems, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, USA; Center for Computational Analysis of Social and Organizational Systems, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
Publication Title: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
Abstract: Decision makers need capabilities to quickly model and effectively assess consequences of actions and reactions in crisis de-escalation environments. The creation and what-if exercising of such models has traditionally had onerous resource requirements. This research demonstrates fast and viable ways to build such models in operational environments. Through social network extraction from texts, network analytics to identify key actors, and then simulation to assess alternative interventions, advisors can support practicing and execution of crisis de-escalation activities. We describe how we used this approach as part of a scenario-driven modeling effort. We demonstrate the strength of moving from data to models and the advantages of data-driven simulation, which allow for iterative refinement. We conclude with a discussion of the limitations of this approach and anticipated future work.
Author Keywords: Computer simulation;information diffusion;social network analysis;text mining
IEEE Terms: Social network services;Analytical models;Data models;Computational modeling;Mathematical model;Cybernetics;Buildings

Document Title: A Review of Computational Intelligence‐Based Biometric Recognition Methods
Authors: T. IlamParithi; K. A. Sudha; D. Jessintha
Author Affiliations: Government Arts and Science College, Sankarankovil, India; Einstein College of Engineering, Tirunelveli, India; Easwari Engineering College, Chennai, India
Abstract:
Summary

In recent years, technology has grown rapidly and technology usage also increased massively. With the help of technology, pupils started to think and act much smarter. A biometric system consists of a device, a sensor, methods, techniques, etc. To find a match to a person, the system uses his physical features such as iris, palm, fingerprint, face, etc. Computational intelligence (CI) methods are commonly used to create biometric identity and overcome non‐idealities that are frequent in datasets. Common types include sample augmentation, feature extraction, categorization, indexing, fusion, normalization, and anti‐spoofing. Computational intelligence plays a vital role in conducting sophisticated nonlinear calculations by developing models from training data in this environment. These methods employ both supervised and unsupervised training procedures. This work presents a review of computational intelligence‐based biometric recognition methods.
IEEE Terms: Biometrics;Computational intelligence;Face recognition;Fingerprint recognition;Kernel;Biological neural networks;Support vector machines;Iris recognition;Fuzzy logic;Artificial neural networks

Document Title: A model of spatial thinking for computational intelligence
Author Affiliations: Relevance Research & Development Corporation, Kharkov National University of Radioelectronics, Ukraine
Abstract: Trying to be effective (no matter who exactly and in what field) a person face the problem which inevitably destroys all our attempts to easily get to a desired goal. The problem is the existence of some insuperable barriers for our mind, another words barriers for principles of thinking. They are our clue and main reason for research. Here we investigate these barriers and their features exposing the nature of mental process. We start from special structures which reflect the ways to define relations between objects. Then we came to realizing about what is the material our mind uses to build thoughts, to make conclusions, to understand, to form reasoning, etc. This can be called a mental dynamics. After this the nature of mental barriers on the required level of abstraction as well as the ways to pass through them became clear. We begin to understand why thinking flows in such a way, with such specifics and with such limitations we can observe in reality. This can help us to be more optimal. At the final step we start to understand, what mathematical models can be applied to such a picture. We start to express our thoughts in a language of mathematics, developing an apparatus for our Spatial Theory of Mind, suitable to represent processes and infrastructure of thinking. We use abstract algebra and stay invariant in relation to the nature of objects.

Document Title: Compositional Thinking in Cyberphysical Systems Theory
Authors: G. Bakirtzis; E. Subrahmanian; C. H. Fleming
Author Affiliations: University of Virginia; Carnegie Mellon University; Iowa State University
Abstract: Engineering safe and secure cyberphysical systems requires system engineers to develop and maintain a number of model views, both dynamic and static. Verifying the composition of requirement, behavioral, and architectural models using category theory gives rise to a strictly compositional interpretation of cyberphysical systems theory.
Funding Information: SERC(grant numbers:HQ0034-13-D-0004); National Science Foundation(grant numbers:1739333); NASA(grant numbers:NNX16AK47A);

Document Title: The Utility of Enterprise Architecture to Records and Archives Specialists
Author Affiliations: University of South Africa, Pretoria, Gauteng, ZA
Publication Title: 2018 IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data)
Abstract: Modern institutions invest large amounts of resources to build technology platforms and business applications to support organizational activities which will fulfil their institutional mandate. Enterprise architecture (EA) has emerged as an approach to improve the alignment between the organization's business and their technology platforms. This article is drawn from a research project investigating the utility of EA for records and archives specialists.
IEEE Terms: Adaptation models;Computational modeling;Conferences;Metadata;Big Data;Systems thinking;Best practices

Document Title: A system thinking approach for time dependent availability analysis of multi component systems
Authors: M. Srinivasa Rao; V. N. A. Naikan
Author Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, GMR Institute of Technology, Rajam, Andhra Pradesh, India; Reliability Engineering Centre, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Publication Title: 2010 2nd International Conference on Reliability, Safety and Hazard - Risk-Based Technologies and Physics-of-Failure Methods (ICRESH)
Abstract: The focus of this paper is on the time dependent availability modeling and analysis of repairable multi component systems. Analytical techniques become very complicated and unrealistic especially for modern complex systems. There have been attempts in the literature to evolve more realistic techniques using simulation approach for availability analysis of systems. This paper proposes a hybrid approach called as Markov System Dynamics (MSD) approach which combines the Markov approach with system dynamics simulation approach for the time dependent availability analysis and to study the dynamic behavior of systems. To the best of the authors' knowledge, in the published literature the authors generally assume that repairable systems reach their steady state when operational time reaches infinity. However, in practical situations it is important to know at what time the steady state begins. Therefore, another objective of this paper is to evaluate the time at which repairable multi component systems reach their steady state of operations. The proposed framework is illustrated for multi component systems such as a three component system with one component on standby with a numerical example. The results of the simulation when compared with that obtained by traditional Markov analysis clearly validate the Markov System Dynamics (MSD) approach as an alternative approach for the time dependent availability analysis.
Author Keywords: Simulation approach;time dependent availability analysis;Markov approach;complex systems;system dynamics;Markov System Dynamics

Document Title: Re-thinking Pitfalls of Premodel Building for Adaptive CNNs Model Selection on ImageNet
Authors: V. Yarovenko; J. -G. Park; M. -H. Lee
Author Affiliations: Computer Science Department, SEDS, Nazarbayev University, Nur-Sultan, Kazakhstan; Computer Science Department, SEDS, Nazarbayev University, Nur-Sultan, Kazakhstan; Computer Science Department, SEDS, Nazarbayev University, Nur-Sultan, Kazakhstan
Publication Title: 2022 4th International Conference on Advances in Computer Technology, Information Science and Communications (CTISC)
Abstract: Although recent approaches to combine machine learning (ML) enhanced models and adaptive model selections using the built models became popular in many areas, however, there could be crucial pitfalls of built models in terms of 1) feature extraction and importance, 2) unbalanced datasets and 3) different types of ML estimators. In this case study using the ImageNet dataset, we thoroughly investigate the effects and possible pitfalls of features, datasets, and ML estimators for adaptive model selection of CNN inference network models targeting embedded systems. Based on the comprehensive results and analysis, we summarize opportunistic alternatives to minimize the pitfalls in the model building phase using more accurate feature extraction algorithms, various datasets in balance and size, and different types of interpretable (explaining important features) and black-box models.
IEEE Terms: Adaptation models;Maximum likelihood estimation;Analytical models;Information science;Embedded systems;Computational modeling;Buildings

Document Title: Think globally, communicate, act locally: online parallel/distributed supervisory control
Authors: N. B. Hadj-Alouane; S. Lafortune; Feng Lin
Author Affiliations: Department of EECS, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; Department of EECS, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; Department of ECE, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, USA
Publication Title: Proceedings of 1994 33rd IEEE Conference on Decision and Control
Abstract: We propose a new algorithm for the online supervisory control of partially observed discrete event systems. This algorithm is a parallel/distributed version of the online algorithm VLP-PO that we proposed in prior work. The situation under consideration in this paper is that of a system whose structure can be expressed as the shuffle of three state machines G/sub 1/, G/sub 12/, and G/sub 2/ (with disjoint event sets), where G/sub 12/ is to be interpreted as a common interface between the two system components G/sub 1/ and G/sub 2/. The legal language, denoted K, is global, but it can also be expressed as the parallel composition of two languages, K/sup 1//spl par/K/sup 2/, where K/sup i//spl sube/L(G/sub i//spl par/G/sub 12/), i=1,2. There are two communicating agents that simultaneously run (online) identical versions of the algorithm but on different models and legal languages: agent i, i=1, 2, operates on subsystem G/sub i//spl par/G/sub 12/ and legal language K/sup i/. We show that this scheme achieves the same behavior as the sequential VLP-PO algorithm, but at a total execution complexity that is significantly lower; this algorithm generates maximal observable and controllable sublanguages of the given legal language K.<>
IEEE Terms: Supervisory control;Law;Legal factors;Control systems;Discrete event systems;Computational complexity;Specification languages;State-space methods
